titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Howard Morehead photographs and papers PASC-M.0142
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Doug Johnson, May, 2016; Caroline Cub√©.

p.date: Online finding aid last updated 2 February 2017; 29 January 2026.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2026-01-29 11:01:50 -0800.

physdesc.extent: (12 boxes, 4 shoe boxes, 6 flat boxes, 3 oversize flat boxes)

did.abstract: Howard Morehead was a photographer, broadcast news cameraman, and impresario. A native of Topeka, Kansas, he moved to Los Angeles after World War II and joined the staff of the Los Angeles Sentinel and did freelance work for a number of magazines. He also founded the Miss Bronze California beauty pageant as a reaction to the systematic discrimination faced by African American women. The collection consists predominantly of photographs of musicians and venues documenting the Los Angeles jazz scene from the mid-1950s through the 1990s. There are also a number of actors and politicians represented. There is a very large amount of glamour photography featuring models and beauty pageant contestants. Some personal and business papers are also present, as well as books, videotapes, and sound recordings from Morehead's personal collection.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Conditions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Howard Morehead Photographs and Papers (Collection PASC-M 142). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Problematic Content and Description in UCLA's library collections and archives.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Howard Morehead was born in Topeka, Kansas in 1926. After graduating from high school, he enlisted in the Army Air Corps and was assigned to Tuskegee Army Airfield, where he began training as a pilot in anticipation of joining the pioneering Tuskegee Airmen. The war ended before he saw combat, and after his discharge from the military he moved to Los Angeles.

After earning a degree in photography from Los Angeles City College, he joined the staff of the Los Angeles Sentinel newspaper in 1950, and also freelanced for various magazines. Eventually he became the first West Coast staff photographer for Johnson Publishing Company, contributing stories and covers for Ebony and Jet. A fan of jazz music, Morehead photographed many of the important musicians of his time, as well as many actors and politicians.

His interest in glamour photography and his awareness of racial discrimination inspired him to found the Miss Bronze L.A. beauty contest in 1958, which soon expanded into the Miss Bronze California pageant, affording African American women the opportunity to compete. In 1970, Morehead became the first African American hired as a staff cameraman for a Los Angeles television station when he began working for KTLA. After a year, he moved to KABC, where he spent seventeen years as a cameraman before retiring.
Morehead continued to document the Los Angeles jazz scene throughout the 1990s. He died in July, 2003.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection predominantly consists of photographs taken by Morehead, mostly of musicians and venues in Los Angeles from the mid-1950s through the 1990s. Subjects include Ray Charles, Miles Davis, Billie Holiday, and many others. There are also a number of actors and politicians represented, including Diahann Carroll, Redd Foxx, John F. Kennedy, and Martin Luther King, Jr. Many of the most important photographs from Morehead's early career exist only as a single image. For instance, there is one photograph of Dexter Gordon that Morehead clearly favored and replicated numerous times in different contexts. But there is no negative of that photograph and no other images from the photo session.

There are, however, voluminous examples of glamour photography, with thousands of negatives of would-be models and actresses posing in attitudes ranging from chaste portraiture to provocative nudity. Many of these photographs were related to the beauty contests organized by Morehead.

The collection also includes some personal and business papers, as well as books, videotapes, and sound recordings from his personal collection. Of particular interest in the papers is Morehead's correspondence with Playboy, which repeatedly rebuffed his attempts to sell photographs of women of color to the magazine. Also noteworthy are documents pertaining to Morehead's employment at KABC-TV, where he was reprimanded numerous times over the years, eventually prompting him to file a racial-discrimination lawsuit.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
The collection is organized into the following series:
Series 1. Photographs
Series 2. Business and personal papers
Series 3. Video cassettes
Series 4. Sound recordings
Series 5. Scrapbooks
Series 6. Books

altformavail.head: Related Online Items Available
altformavail.p: Portions of the Howard Morehead photographs and papers have been digitized and are available online: Howard Morehead photographs and papers (182 items)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains black-and-white and color prints; 35mm, 120, and 3x4 negatives; proof sheets; transparencies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains portraits and candid shots of musicians, actors, politicians, and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: 3 prints; 26 negatives; proof sheet. At Union Station, Los Angeles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 1 print; 75 negatives [print is after first Sonny Liston bout; the negatives may be on the occasion of Ali's final fight in 1981].

scopecontent.p: Approximately 230 negatives. Though not credited to Morehead, the image on the band's Wikipedia page on 5/2/23 is clearly from this photo session. That image is dated 1969 November 20.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 92 negatives; proof sheet fragment; 1 matted print.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: SERIES CONTAINS AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: Audiovisual materials in this series will require assessment and possible digitization for safe access. To review these audiovisual materials, you must notify the UCLA Library Special Collections Reference Desk in advance of your visit.

accessrestrict.p: Use of electronic/digital format material requires special equipment or further processing may be required for viewing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence and other documents regarding Morehead's various business ventures and his employment at KABC. Files including the word "incident" contain material regarding disciplinary measures taken against Morehead at the television station, which cumulatively resulted in him filing a racial-discrimination lawsuit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Includes model questionnaires and resumes; press releases.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence regarding the donation of Morehead's papers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Includes Black Is More Than Beautiful beefcake cards.

did.unittitle: City of Angels Jazz Festival program

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Includes article about Edwards by Morehead.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains mock-up of proposed book of photography.

did.unittitle: Lena Horne: The Lady and Her Music program

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Elegant, 1:6, 2:3 [with feature on Eartha Kitt photographed by Morehead], 2:6, 2:8; Players, 17:11.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes letters from Playboy explaining that they do not consider "foreign, Oriental and Negro girls" as models.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Mostly home recordings; VHS tapes unless otherwise noted.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: RESTRICTED ACCESS: Use of moving image material requires production of viewing copies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains clippings and covers from publications targeting African-American readers, including the Los Angeles Sentinel, Ebony, Tan, Jet, Sepia, and Hue; application to join the American Society of Magazine Photographers.
